sect1.title: Purpose
sect1.para: This software manual has been written to document the 2.0 series of Cedar Backup, originally released in early 2005.

sect1.title: Audience
sect1.para: This book is written for computer-literate administrators who need to use and configure Cedar Backup on their Linux system. The examples in this book assume the reader is relatively comfortable with Unix and command-line interfaces.

sect1.title: Conventions Used in This Book
sect1.para: This section covers the various conventions used in this book.

listitem.para: Provides some background about how Cedar Backup came to be, its history, some general information about what needs it is intended to meet, etc.
Discusses the basic concepts of a Cedar Backup infrastructure, and specifies terms used throughout the rest of the manual.
Explains how to install and configure the Cedar Backup package either from the Python source distribution or from the Debian package.
Provides detailed information about how to configure Cedar Backup.
Discusses general troubleshooting techniques and provides information about how to read the logfile, interpret debugging information, etc., etc.

Provides some details about the internals of the software and rationale behind certain design choices, etc. Also discusses the Cedar Backup extension architecture. Users would not typically need to read this chapter, but extension developers or programmers debugging problems or implementing enhancements may find it useful.

Covers the major differences between the current Cedar Backup release and the previous 1.0 release. Differences are generally noted in the appropriate sections throughout the text of the manual, but some users might be interested in seeing a concise summary of the differences.
Specifies the Cedar Backup extension architecture interface, through which third party developers can write extensions to Cedar Backup.

sect1.title: Acknowledgments
sect1.para: The structure of this book and some of the basic boilerplate has been taken from the book Version Control with Subversion. Many thanks to the authors (and O'Reilly) for making this excellent reference available under a free and open license.
